channel.title: Python version and IDEs?
channel.description:
It's been awhile since I wrote much python code, and then it was generally just small projects for school involving a handful of files and I wrote them in a text editor like Kate, and it was python 2.5 I believe. Now I plan on writing what will probably become a rather large project, and am wondering two things.
1. what version of python I should use and why? (2.x or 3.x) 2. Any good python IDEs? I've heard about Eric and Eclipse+PyDev.
Thanks if you can help me any.

item.title: Python version and IDEs?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

2.6 all the way!

Read full topic

item.title: Python version and IDEs?
item.dc:creator: @cruel cruel
item.description:
@cruel wrote:

Ya, like Yume said, too many projects using 2.X
So I use 2.7 though I often use future imports for some 3.0 functionality I like. Like the division of 3.0, I like it turning 2 / 3 into 0.6667 instead of an integer 0, then I don’t have to type cast everything into float or w/e.

Read full topic

item.title: Python version and IDEs?
item.dc:creator: @Yume Yume
item.description:
@Yume wrote:

I would suggest writing in Python 2.7, trying to write for 3.0 compatibility for later porting.

(Use print(“abc”) rather than print “abc” and so on). 3.0 lacks support from lots of 3rd party modules.

Read full topic

item.title: Python version and IDEs?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Hmm, I do like IntelliJ, so I’ll certainly give PyCharm a shot. I wanted to play around with Django anyway, so that functionality might be good.

What about the version cruel? Would you write a new project in 2.X or 3?

In case any of you are wondering, I of course haven’t started anything yet.

Read full topic

item.title: Python version and IDEs?
item.dc:creator: @cruel cruel
item.description:
@cruel wrote:

I already suggested it in the web dev board, but I like PyCharm. It’s made by Jetbrains, so looks just like IntelliJ. It stresses some functionality for Django and Google App Engine, but it can obviously do any generic python project.

Read full topic

item.title: Python version and IDEs?
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:12, topic:420177”][quote author=STH link=topic=522735.msg3806467#msg3806467 date=1320514604]

Like I said, I don’t need any GUIs, at least with this program, so that’s not an issue. I didn’t know netbeans supported python development? Is there a specific plugin I need to look for? I have always liked netbeans.

I think I’m going to have to research some on the differences between 2.X and 3.X, and figure out which way I want to go. Unless mopman convinces me to use ruby before then I guess.

Almost every library I’ve ever needed is compiled for 64bit and 32bit versions of 2.7.2. That is not the case with 3.x.

For Netbeans, you will have to download a plugin for the Python support.
[/quote]

I’ve never had any problems compiling my own libraries if need be.[/quote]

The problem is that it’s not just that simple. There are many backwards-incompatibilities in 3.x that makes compiling 2.x modules in 3.x more difficult, or else they all would have been compiled by now.

Read full topic

item.title: Python version and IDEs?
item.dc:creator: @Phillipe Phillipé
item.description:
@Phillipe wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:9, topic:420177”]Like I said, I don’t need any GUIs, at least with this program, so that’s not an issue. I didn’t know netbeans supported python development? Is there a specific plugin I need to look for? I have always liked netbeans.

I think I’m going to have to research some on the differences between 2.X and 3.X, and figure out which way I want to go. Unless mopman convinces me to use ruby before then I guess. :)[/quote]

PyDev is one of the java ide plugins for Python IIRC.

TL;DR of 2.7 is sped up io module, tiling in tk, automatic field numbering and no futher dev.

Read full topic

item.title: Python version and IDEs?
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

2.7.2 is what I use, along with wxPython for GUIs. I like Komodo but Komodo Edit (free) lacks versioning, but I’ve used Netbeans 6.9 for a while and I’m fine with that.

I think it will be a very long time until I switch to 3.x, if ever.

Read full topic

item.title: Python version and IDEs?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

http://www.geany.org/ is decent

Read full topic

item.title: Python version and IDEs?
item.dc:creator: @Phillipe Phillipé
item.description:
@Phillipe wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:1, topic:420177”]It’s been awhile since I wrote much python code, and then it was generally just small projects for school involving a handful of files and I wrote them in a text editor like Kate, and it was python 2.5 I believe. Now I plan on writing what will probably become a rather large project, and am wondering two things.

  1. what version of python I should use and why? (2.x or 3.x)
  2. Any good python IDEs? I’ve heard about Eric and Eclipse+PyDev.

Thanks if you can help me any.[/quote]

I’d stick with at the latest 2.7 for the version and for the IDE I’ve always rolled SPE.

Read full topic

item.title: Python version and IDEs?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:4, topic:420177”][quote author=Mopman link=topic=522735.msg3802088#msg3802088 date=1320106595]
I’m afraid I can’t help you much as I’m not a Python guy, but I’m curious what you expect to gain from an IDE that you’re not getting from your standard editor.

Not out to start a war, everyone already knows I’m pretty anti-IDE, just genuinely wondering what you feel you’re missing.
[/quote]

Good question. A few things would be nice.

  1. Auto-completion: Kate has this, and it’s nice, but of course it doesn’t know anything about python, different classes, or different files, so it won’t fill in everything that it could like a python IDE could.
  2. ctrl+click to go to class, field, or method clicked on. I don’t know how to quite explain this, do you know what I mean?
    Ie, I’m in class A, I call a method from class B there, called foo, like so: bee = new b; bee.foo(something), I want to know what .foo does, so I can hold ctrl and click on it and it takes me there. Much better than searching through source code for it. It’s pretty standard in Java IDEs.
  3. Lastly, things I could probably script in an editor like kate, like compile and run buttons. Maybe git integration? I don’t know, sometimes that more gets in the way than just doing it from the command line.

You don’t use any of those for ruby? Also, I guess I could use ruby for this project, if I have to learn some new stuff for python 3 then maybe I will. Meh.

Use 2.6, most people still use it. 3 doesn’t have gui stuff ported yet (as of last year?) and has slightly different object construction - I don’t think they changed much. I used gedit/pydev for eclipse.

Yes, 2.6, that was it. I don’t need any GUI stuff, it’s going to do a lot of parsing of web pages and storing that data in a database like mysql, so any front-end I use will be web based. So based on that should I go ahead and use 3?[/quote]
I don’t recall eclipse having auto-completion (or it did, but it was inconsistent) . gedit on the other hand has none. I’ve sort of gotten used to not having auto completion since I started learning c++

Read full topic

item.title: Python version and IDEs?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:2, topic:420177”]I’m afraid I can’t help you much as I’m not a Python guy, but I’m curious what you expect to gain from an IDE that you’re not getting from your standard editor.

Not out to start a war, everyone already knows I’m pretty anti-IDE, just genuinely wondering what you feel you’re missing.[/quote]

Good question. A few things would be nice.

  1. Auto-completion: Kate has this, and it’s nice, but of course it doesn’t know anything about python, different classes, or different files, so it won’t fill in everything that it could like a python IDE could.
  2. ctrl+click to go to class, field, or method clicked on. I don’t know how to quite explain this, do you know what I mean?
    Ie, I’m in class A, I call a method from class B there, called foo, like so: bee = new b; bee.foo(something), I want to know what .foo does, so I can hold ctrl and click on it and it takes me there. Much better than searching through source code for it. It’s pretty standard in Java IDEs.
  3. Lastly, things I could probably script in an editor like kate, like compile and run buttons. Maybe git integration? I don’t know, sometimes that more gets in the way than just doing it from the command line.

You don’t use any of those for ruby? Also, I guess I could use ruby for this project, if I have to learn some new stuff for python 3 then maybe I will. Meh.

t4:

Use 2.6, most people still use it. 3 doesn’t have gui stuff ported yet (as of last year?) and has slightly different object construction - I don’t think they changed much. I used gedit/pydev for eclipse.

Yes, 2.6, that was it. I don’t need any GUI stuff, it’s going to do a lot of parsing of web pages and storing that data in a database like mysql, so any front-end I use will be web based. So based on that should I go ahead and use 3?

Read full topic
